pros: Flexible and lots of autonomy
cons: Pay isn't as competitive. Office is pretty empty making trips to campus feeling a bit deserted.

pros: Time off, pay, bonus, University's mission/values
cons: Silo environment can be negative

pros: yearly bonus. work from home opportunities.
cons: lack of transparency from management. job duties will constantly change.

pros:
Bellevue University has many students through The Guild (a program that offers free tuition for many corporations like Walmart, Target, Disney, Kohls, Chipolte). 
The University has been online for over a dozen years.
cons:
Bellevue University is one of the worst-paying online Universities. We've lost many good employees because of this. 

Leadership expects faculty (full-time and adjunct) to work 7 days a week to answer student questions. Faculty are not offered any time-off. This results in very poor work-life balance and employee burn-out. 

The systems in place at the University are very old and dated. There is little effort to fix ongoing problems. (They'll meet 20 times rehashing issues without implementing simple solutions.)

job_title: AVP/Dean of Students in Bellevue, NE
pros: Outstanding leadership, great employees, University cares for their employees and students, open access University. People who care about each other and the students. Benefits are competitive and the bonus is a nice.
cons: None at this time, the University has been very good to me and my family.

pros: Good pay for anyone coming straight out of college.
cons: It's no longer a fun place to work. I felt like a number and was not rewarded for hard work or innovative ideas.

job_title: Senior Graphic Designer in Bellevue, NE
pros: Feeling of pride in my work
cons: non-profit, so the pay is on the low end of the medium

job_title: Assistant Vice President in Omaha, NE
pros: Strong institution for student outcomes; growing and sustaining growth
cons: Terrible pay; President believes you should be happy with what you agreed to on day one for salary

pros:
They assign me similar courses so I don't have to continue to prep. I can revise previous instruction. 

They set the syllabus and curriculum for you, and those can't be changed. Your job is the instruction.
cons: Sometimes the assignments are a bit stale.

pros: Great work place. Flexible hours. Good bosses, great co workers.
cons: Close to none. University could expand.

pros:
Making a difference daily in people's lives.
Working with outstanding people.
cons:
Areas tend to be compartmentalized, making collaboration difficult.
Stark difference between operational and educational side in terms of corporate culture.

pros: Good training and great colleagues
cons: Nothing major that comes to mind

pros:
Beautiful campus
Great, supportive peers
Extra Money
cons:
Put up with a lot for peanuts on the dollar
No support from management 
Rules are contradictory

job_title: Senior Director, Marketing in Omaha, NE
pros: It doesn't surprise me that Bellevue University was named a Great College to Work For. Innovation for the student success comes first in every decision. And the leadership is truly committed to taking care of staff and faculty as well as students!
cons: Always new opportunities and challenges, which is motivating and inspiring.

pros: Flexible, market-driven, agile, innovative, creative
cons: location, reputation, facilities, opportunity to advance

job_title: Financial Aid Specialist in Bellevue, NE
pros: Great team to work with, consistent work, overall not a bad job.
cons: Micromanagement made it impossible to be fully productive.

pros: Great place to work as a full time and tuition is free
cons: Due to COVID-19 not everyone is here but you can meet your team via zoom.

job_title: Senior IT Manager in Bellevue, NE
pros: Good people to work with
cons: Leadership can change quickly at times

pros: Most of the people that work there genuinely care about students and offering quality learning programs.  Some of the academic programs are world class, but others seriously lack relevancy and the curriculum is elementary level at best. Great benefits - some of the best anywhere around: tuition assistance for employee and family, matching 403b (up to 8%), and good health insurance for single people ($69 avg/mon).  It gets expensive if you are getting coverage for a family ($500+/mon).
cons: Culture has changed to have a more "corporate" feel.  Everything is about the bottom line and revenue generation.  Lack of students on campus.  Most advising and enrollment is done online and over the phone.  Students may never actually meet their advisor. Online platform is antiquated even though they continue to do updates.  It is still not as robust as what it could be. Lack of guidance for how to get promoted - there are no clear pathways.  It seems that most people are hand selected based on favoritism.

review_title: Used to be Great, now it is horrible
pros:
Hours are good.
Some people are great.
Try to help people by educating them.
Great to see some people be the first in their families to graduate.
Benefits are pretty good, although very expensive.
cons:
Treat employees like idiots.
Do not listen to employees and do not care what employees think.
Constantly adding responsibilities and workload without compensation or collaboration.
Senior management have no respect for employees.
Ask for input but do not want any unless you agree with senior management.
Constantly hiring more people to correct mistakes that could have been avoided.
If you do not agree with deans or vpaa you will be shunned and/or mocked.
Egotistical managers, their way or you are miserable.
Can not trust fellow employees because management has a group of employees who report all rumors, causal discussions, and anything stated in meetings, lunches, or while walking to a car.
A lot of employees (exceptions to the above) would leave if they could.

review_title: Great place to work if you're former military
pros: Room to advance in some areas if they like you.
cons: Some managers are nasty to their staff causing constant turnover.  Tend to get rid of older staff or move them to other areas so they can hire younger and pretty people who don't meet the position requirements.

pros: Benefits, work hours, some employees are a joy to work with, just not enough of them left.
cons: Poor management, lack of support from superiors, poor pay for the region unless you're in management.  This used to be a fun place to work at but the constant poor decision making is unsettling.  Telling employees there is not enough money to pay them yet spending it on whim is not responsible spending.  Skipping a computer upgrade cycle one year then upgrading the same workstations twice within 2 months of each other is simply poor planning and a waste of half a million dollars let alone the disruption for the staff who have to be upgraded.

pros: Employees truly have the opportunity to make a direct impact on people's lives.   The majority of employees/faculty at BU have the rooted core belief of the value of higher education and genuinely want to connect people to it.
cons: As with most of academia, there are a lot of politics involved.  BU works more as a business institution.  So it works as a business that's hyper political.   There is not a clear pathway for progression.   Lots of under-the-table type of promotions or movement.

review_title: Solid pay, terrible culture and ethics.
pros: Salaries are competitive, but that's mostly to compensate for the lack of any type of ethical backbone. If you're willing to put up with all the negativity, ethical bankruptcy and snarkiness you'll probably rise quickly because of the frequent turnover.
cons: This isn't a university so much as just a degree mill and for-profit business. Management is wildly supportive providing you don't question anything, ever. Suggest an idea that the "in group" doesn't like and you'll be openly targeted by coworkers and superiors with zero assistance from HR. Staff is also openly hostile to those with differing political beliefs from the conservative mantra that is trumpeted from founders and funders.

pros: Within the smaller structure of the departments there are great teams and amazing people who care about what they do. Direct managers while overworked do the best they can to take care of their team members.
cons: Once you go up the tier to executive management they care very little for the well-being of those below them. Salaries are low and stagnant, and suggestions for any change is construed as whining. Little to no chance for advancement unless you are a favored few.

pros: BU helped develop me for over eight years. They gave me access to training (you have to take them up on the offer) and professional development, rewarded me with effective motivational tools (a sign of good leadership) and provided a safe work environment. The benefits are decent too which is a plus.
cons: Like I said previously, the benefits were decent but over the course of the eight years, they became more and more expensive. But, with tuition reimbursements and other great retirement benefits, it was hard to explain. Like every job there were some annoying things but that's not unique to BU. There are people everywhere who are motivated by weird stuff or who have a hard time critically thinking through issues so it's not unheard of at BU to see some weird things. That just added to the charm!

pros: Some great people who work (or are trapped) there. Campus is very nice looking although you rarely see anyone walking around.
cons: Business disguised as a university.  Treat students as customers, so employees are considered customer service reps. Must be the worst administrators ever. and watch how they treat you if you disagree.  Had a colleague leave after many stellar accomplishments and she was treated so poorly.  Pay is at low end of scale. There are definitely favorites who receive special treatment, but the rest of us are forced to work a ridiculous amount of hours with little appreciation. If you want to donate years off your life, then this is your place to work.

review_title: Great teaching experience, poor employee experience
pros: You can expect superior support from your college's administrative and academic support services.  Very helpful, flexible and prompt when needed.  Great at helping you with grading challenges or student issues.  Can't say enough great things about feeling supported even when teaching online remotely by the staff of the college for which I am teaching.
cons: The school's general administrative staff and processes for prehistoric. The concept of serving employees is completely lost.  When I have a problem, even when it's admittedly a process problem in their end, I have been told it was my responsibility to point it out at the time otherwise it was NOT their responsibility to correct it.  No concern with getting it right, just being inconvenienced.

pros: Great co-workers. I formed some long lasting relationships through this company and it definitely gave me a leg up in my experience. The tuition remission is AWESOME as long as they don't find a reason to fire you before your time is up.
cons: I worked for the University for 4 years and the first 2 were great. The last 2 were terrible when I was victimized by my manager and let go for no reason 6 months before my remission was done being paid back. There is no back bone or structure and this is NOT an educational institution, they are a full on business who does not care about the well being of their employees. At the time I worked there everyone from HR to lower level management was corrupt. They have far too many directors and give people promotions only to later fire or lay them off.

job_title: Senior Quality Assurance Technician in Omaha, NE
pros: Good benefits, semi-competitive pay, nice facilities, friendly people. Opportunities for advancement can be plentiful but only in the right departments.
cons:
Pay raises are inconsistent. When I was hired I was told everyone got a yearly 4% cost of living raise. I only ever got as high as 3% and that soon dropped to 2%. Currently it's been 15 months since that raise, and there's no sign of another one coming. Employees expressed interest in a pay-for-performance system, which leadership opted to apply to our yearly bonus rather than to a yearly pay raise.

Leadership has no codified system for employee development. It's pretty much just up to you.

review_title: Same Strategy from 10 years ago and 10 years hence
pros: Small intimate university.  Tons of possibilities to make a difference in the Omaha region.  Some great employees who are willing to share their knowledge and experiences - so much talent.
cons: The university is in financial trouble and they don't know how to fix it.  The senior execs (President, EVPs, VPs, etc.) don't seem to understand business principles.  Yes, they are a non-profit but have to make money in order to pay their bills and add new educational programs, hire quality professors and support staff.  The frustration comes from the inability to make decisions, develop a long-term strategy, etc.  It's sad to see this happen.

review_title: Great place to work and learn.
pros: Working in Higher Education has its positives and negatives.  Bellevue University prides itself on being agile and able to meet student's needs.  This is very fun to be part of however at times it can lend itself to disconnects in process design.  Bellevue University's culture allows for this and for some it's a negative but for most it is a positive and our students benefit.
cons: As mentioned previously, the high rate of innovation can cause confusion.  If you're able to embrace innovation and change though, you won't see this as a negative.

pros: The people - the common thread that attracts and retains most on the staff level.  Bellevue University and its staff (for the most part) have heart and work diligently to meet the needs of the students.
cons: Salaries are low due to being a nonprofit but the organization has just added target bonuses and a pay for performance structure so that those who excel have the potential to receive more than their base pay.

pros: The environment as a whole was fairly relaxed.  You know what the day to day is going to be when you walk in the door.
cons: They don't value their employees.  They will pay the very minimum they can get away with, and when you let them know things are not as they should be they will reply with "Then leave there are 100 people waiting to take your job."

review_title: Waiting until the go out of business or I find a new job.
pros: The benefits are OK, we have good athletic teams, some of coworkers are fun to work with and be around.  Closed for holidays and bonus checks.
cons:
Management does not know what they are doing.
Egotistical management, they act like they invented education.
Management has to have it their way, any other way is not right or not possible.
Work increases pay does not.
Management imposes veiled threats all the time.
Meetings all the time to listen to management tell you how smart they are and how we all need to come together (which means accept their plan).

pros: Generous time off - likely to prevent employees from going insane.
cons: Leadership and management is horribly disconnected with the reality of many aspects of daily operations and have been frequently misguided by manipulative individuals and jump to eagerly into risky opportunities for rapid expansion that ultimately undercut the infrastructure's/employees' ability to keep up.

pros: Flexibility to do my job from anywhere on my own time.  I get a fair amount of autonomy in the way I do my job.  Nontraditonal students with work experience and strong desire to improve themselves.
cons: Administratively, I had to keep on top of everything myself when hired.  Curriculum is extremely prescriptive and doesn't leave much room for influence over the 'how.'

pros:
Some really great people work there. They are dedicated and loyal to the University. Health benefits were pretty good until this year.
Paid time off is generous.
cons:
Some members of upper management don't have the University's best interest at heart. They seem to want to promote their own agenda.  

Only favorites get raises and promotions. This situation is known to all, which makes it very discouraging, and isn't fair to others who also work hard.  After so many years it is disappointing.

pros:
1. There's a lot of really bright people that work there. 
2. You can finish your degree..and your family members can as well
cons:
1. Hello Right Hand, meet Left Hand...  Ahh..if only people could communicate...
2. No raises, just a straight cost of living increase each year.  You get the same as the slacker next to you.
3. Very low wages.

review_title: It used to be a place at which I was proud to work
pros: The location, the benefits are okay for a non-profit, some of the people I work with.
cons: Poor leadership, poor pay, lack of trust and integrity, poor decisions being made, not a fun place to work anymore, focus seems to be more on money and not the students.

review_title: Chaos- Management hasn't figured out how to manage and fiscal irresponsibility runs rampant
pros: Close to the Omaha Metro area. Tuition is free for employees, which enables you to earn a degree without the burden of student loans.
cons: Management has been fiscally irresponsible for years. Now layoffs are in full effect, but no one wants to admit it. The company is out of money and the quality of education they offer is close to a diploma mill. Advancement opportunities are slim to none. Only those willing to spend their time in politics will survive.

review_title: Could be a good place to work if it weren't for the nepotism going on...
pros: The immediate person I reported to was really good with training. Not overwhelming in work load.
cons: Members of the same family working in the same department makes for a very negative work environment and if one member doesn't like you, then you are out. They will actually go OVER your supervisor's head to their family member to complain instead of going through the proper channels. It was so bad I quit a job I was going to really like.

pros: Advancement opportunities, competitive salaries for a nonprofit, generally good benefits including tuition remission. The campus environment is cheerful and employees have access to student amenities like the gym and cafeteria.
cons: Departments are competitive and often find difficulty working together to achieve goals. Communication could improve organization wide. Reorganization and layoffs occur occasionally.

review_title: Great place to work, highly collaborative!
pros:
-  Flexible with great work-life balance
- Highly collaborative
- Non-profit
- A corporate mission that makes a difference (education) in this world
- New facilities
- Great retirement plan and benefits
- Worker friendly environment
- 100% tuition reimbursement for employee and family
cons:
- Non-profit pay
- Initial vacation allotment is low
- Lack of corporate-sponsored mobile devices (bring your own)
- Campus location is off the beaten path

job_title: Systems Support Coordinator in Bellevue, NE
pros: I was able to get my Master's degree free while employed at B.U.
cons: No room for growth once I received my MSMIS degree at B.U.

pros: Parking is fairly close to the building, although you can only park 4 rows back in the lot to make room for students and more important people, like the president and board members. Weekends and holidays off. Daytime hours. That's about it.
cons:
The reason I said to not believe the positive reviews is because those are put out there by directors and higher-paid employees to make the university look better. They did the same with another online job review site, jobvent.com There were 10 negative reviews that mysteriously disappeared and were replaced with 3 stellar reviews all created on the same day. Shady, shady, shady. Some of the reviews may be legitimate, but I wouldn't hold your breath.

Management is constantly breathing down your neck to meet an enrollment quota that is unattainable given the current state of higher education. The recession is over and less people are going back to college. BU does not realize this, and increases goal every term, making it harder and harder to reach. When your raise is dependent upon your goal (they try to say it's based upon your reviews from students on your performance, but we all know that's not all) it makes it difficult to stay positive because you never know if your work is being appreciated.

Another note on the performance reviews - these are done by students and give a blanket overview of the entire enrollment experience from beginning to end. If that student had a poor interaction with someone in another department and decide to give every department a bad score, that score will affect you and your raise. Not entirely fair, in my opinion.

Directors and managers also place undue stress on employees and ask employees to stay late, come in on weekends, etc. If you are a salaried employee, these extra hours are unpaid. Then, you'll see every manager and director strolling out of the building at 5:00 pm on the dot, while you're stuck at your desk mindlessly working away.

The pay is horrendous for higher education. I know that not everyone takes a job because of pay, but when you have been with a company for years and are barely making $35K, that shows you something. I have seen other colleges and universities who start their employees out close to $50K. BU does offer a yearly bonus, which is a plus. The only drawback to that is the percentage fluctuates every year (it's normally between 10-20%) and then it's taxed 40% because it's considered a "gift".

All in all, it's not a positive work environment and not a job I hope to keep.

review_title: Completely Unorganized, Misguided Management, Lack of Consistant Policies and Guidelines & Sometimes Downright Unethical
pros: It was very casual. I could wear jeans in my particular department, which was nice. (This does not hold true across the entire University.) There weren't very many standards or goals in place, so it's easy to just kind of hide and float along if that's what you're looking for. The work-life balance is great, people often came in at 9 a.m. and left by 3 p.m. The benefits were mediocre, but decent enough. The bonus was nice, but fluctuated a lot and was not always guaranteed.
cons:
Everyone seems to be a floater. A lot of complacency. It's extremely difficult to get fired. Poor performance or unethical behavior isn't even enough to get you fired. There's no focus on career paths, or individual career growth and development. If you like to float, that's great. If you're someone who actually wants to work, with passion for the job you were hired to do, stay far away. You will be very unhappy here. If you're into popularity contests, there's always the chance that you'll get lucky, and one of the senior managers will take an interest in your career and prop you up. But their interest is usually completely based on favoritism and not the typical qualities of managers, especially not talent, skills or work ethic. 

Unfortunately, this management/promotional tactic results in a lot of managers who don't have good people skills, haven't really done the work to earn the position, and worst of all: don't connect with their employees, and don't have a good understanding of how their employees get their work done every day. Because the managers don't really know what their employees are interested in, or even what they're good at, a lot of money is wasted on outsourcing things. Because everything is outsourced, employees sit empty handed, working on small, unimportant projects. They even hired a firm to come up with a name for a new program. The name was so terrible that it's not even in use anymore, because it didn't resonate with the target audience.

pros: Pay is comparable.  Good flexibility.
cons: Generally very poor leadership at the executive down to the mid-level management level, mainly due to extremely poor leadership and autocratic approach from the top.  Decisions are made at the top and directed to employees.  No involvement in decision-making related to my specific area.  Poor communication, complete lack of trust in senior team.

review_title: Good people have left or are looking elsewhere
pros: It's a semi-collegiate atmosphere located in the Midwest. Managers go out of their way to give you stickers instead of feedback.
cons: Over 90 people have either left or been let go recently. Many people are scared and looking for employment in other areas.

pros: Flexible company with management that cares. Nature of work is rewarding. Bonus each year, competitive salary.
cons: Human Resources makes errors regularly. Management and Directors have relatively no power, actions are dictated by Vice President and President only. Promotions are largely based upon

pros: Great benefits, including excellent 403B retirement plan, great people to work with, events are fun to volunteer at.
cons: If enrollment drops, beware of layoffs. Very strong political minds that may not agree with you, so be careful - it is a university environment.

job_title: Not Willing to State in Bellevue, NE
pros: A very progressive institution. Adapts to emerging education trends. Students are the first priority. This is an excellent place to work.
cons: The University rapidly changed from feeling more like a family to near-big corporation business processes. Fair opportunity for career advancement.

review_title: Bellevue University is a wonderful institution with great employees.
pros: Students needs come first and employees are listened to in this regard.  The benefits are quite good.  Communication and collaboration are excellent.
cons: Pay is seriously below the average for this city.  IT is better compensated than other areas

pros: Thorough training, easy layout of online classrooms to teach, friendly staff.  Love that IT is only one call away and they are very helpful!
cons: No concerns with this University

pros: It is a great place to explore, learn fro international students. They held various workshops on career building aspects as communication, mock interview, resume preparation etc. The manager and coach were very passionate about helping the students.
cons: There aren't many big companies associated with the University

review_title: Online Adjunct at Bellevue -- Overall, a good job.
pros: Can work remotely.  Well paid for the amount of hours I put in .  Outstanding faculty who are great to work with.  Good students doing interesting work.
cons: Usual bureaucracy at a university.

pros: It was close to home, other than that.....there are no positives
cons: Everything!  BEWARE!  You will do a lot of work for little pay while the Executives take the 25% bonuses and get huge increases in pay.

pros: Supportive teamwork, flexible work styles,  interesting work in a mission-focused non-profit higher education culture.
cons: If you are highly technical, earning potential may not be as high as at a for-profit org.

review_title: The University is turning  progressively “For Profit”
pros: Flexible schedule, cheap benefits, eh
cons: Pay, advancement opportunities, nepotism. Poor culture, for profit feeling,

pros: Great people to work with.  Encouraged to think outside the box.
cons: Lack of transparency. Top down management.  Workload is unreasonable.

pros: I loved the environment around me and the co-works.
cons: I did not like the management and how they treated the

pros: It's non-profit (sort of). Work/life balance is pretty good.
cons: Culture is non-transparent and there is very little collaboration.

pros: The level of autonomy is a plus.
cons: There is very little growth/advancement opportunity.

pros: Work from home, diversity of students, good support from Director, great IT support when needed.
cons: Hours you can teach as Adjunct are limited.

pros: The are recognized for their programs across the US
cons: Growing pains and becoming more of a business culture than an innovative culture.

pros: good salary,flexible timing really nice place to start the 1st job
cons: nothing much of a downside to talk about

pros: Close to where I live.
cons: The university needs to have more night classes instead of more online classes.

pros: Great place to work, communication among team is always open and everyone is willing to help.
cons: No cons at this time!

pros: A good place to start

pros: very comfortable working place and smooth coworker relationship

pros: Friendly people, environment easy to work at
